pullRequest.title: Variable precision timestamp support for Hive write operations
pullRequest.bodyText: Write path for timestamps now honors the precision specified in the Hive config (or session).  Stats collection is only supported for millisecond precision; when a higher precision is specified, timestamp columns will be ignored for the purpose of collecting stats.  The limitation will be addressed when #5170 is implemented.

afterCommit.message: Variable precision timestamp support for Hive write operations

nodes.bodyText:
compare with TIMESTAMP_MILLIS using ==
(this is intentionally supported; reads better)
IntSupplier -> int

This should be using actual type, not "best type"
pass the type from io.prestosql.plugin.hive.util.FieldSetterFactory#create here and use it

up to millis precision is covered by epochMillis parameter, so
mod MICROSECONDS_PER_SECOND should probably be mod MICROSECONDS_PER_MILLISECOND
This should be using actual type, not "best type"
should we have this for other formats in this class?
Is this relevant? or did you disable stats collection for timestamp != 3 for now?
debug?

nodes.bodyText:
Avoid java.time's objectful representation.
Can we use LongTimestamp or something like DecodedTimestamp (rename to HiveTimestamp?)

nodes.bodyText: @electrum this was not intentional?

i am concerned about perf overhead of using LongTimestamp always.
@dain ?

the conditions should be based on type.precision
the actual block representation can be many different things (like RLEBlock, DictionaryBlock, LazyBlock, etc)

if the type == TIMESTAMP_MILLIS the data coming in should have zeroed out micros part, so the rounding should not be necessary. Is it necessary due to CTAS flow? At least a comment, but we should talk this through.
what are these cases going away now?

nodes.bodyText: Good catch on the unused method, but please remove in a separate commit, since it's unrelated to adding precision support.
This looks like an unrelated cleanup, please move to separate commit.
Either move this into the Hive connector or revert this change -- we shouldn't have a Hive specific class name in the plugin-toolkit module.
Don't wrap here arbitrarily.
This rounding is not needed since we don't support picosecond precision and thus will never have fractional nanos.
Do this change (along with updating callers) in a separate commit.
These variables can be inlined
This rounding is not necessary
We don't need this check as time zones have second precision at most. This would be a major bug in Joda-Time that we shouldn't need to verify for every call.
Bump. This seems not applied (at least not in Handle variable precision timestamps in MaterializedResult commit)

co we have correctness tests ensure
WHERE col < actual_value + 1 nanosecond

doesn't filter out col = actual_value (for col being full millis .... h:m:s.001000000 or not: .... h:m:s.001000001)
link to gh issue about that (#5172 right?)
nit "\\E" is probably redundant
i like the change but it belongs to the prep commit, not Variable precision timestamp support for Hive write operations
why did we gain toIntExact here?

storage_formats tests are run multiple times, on many different environments, since file format behavior may interact with things like kerberos, impersonation
these tests do not need to run multiple times, and i guess they take quite some time (correct?)
we can move them to separate group
or, we can have them without a group (then will be run in suite-1, on multine)
-- in any case it'd be good to document the reason for this in a code comment
or move the tests to a spearate class

nodes.bodyText: here as elswhere: confine epochMicros to each of if/else blocks and have epochSeconds and picosOfSecond as the only things common

This belongs to Add roundDiv overload in Timestamps commit (now it's part of Minor ORC cleanup).
After you move this change, rename Minor ORC cleanup commit to eg Remove unused method

This is no longer correct. We unblock write path with nano precision, but we create column handles with millis.
Instead, we should filter out timestamp columns, if current precision != default precision.
OTOH, since we do  filtering in getStatisticsCollectionMetadata (correct),
i think it could be enough to use getTimestampPrecision(session) here, instead of DEFAULT_PRECISION
and update getType(TypeManager) call 2 lines below
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1214,7 +1214,7 @@ public void finishStatisticsCollection(ConnectorSession session, ConnectorTableH
         List<String> partitionColumnNames = partitionColumns.stream()
                 .map(Column::getName)
                 .collect(toImmutableList());
-        // TODO: revisit when handling write path
+        // TODO: https://github.com/prestosql/presto/issues/5170
         List<HiveColumnHandle> hiveColumnHandles = hiveColumnHandles(table, typeManager, TimestampType.DEFAULT_PRECISION);

nodes.bodyText:
getType(TypeManager) overload is still used; for example io.prestosql.plugin.hive.HiveMetadata#finishCreateTable, io.prestosql.plugin.hive.HiveMetadata#finishInsert call sites look relevant
please make sure there is an issue covering cleanup of the other ones
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -522,7 +523,7 @@ else if (insertExistingPartitionsBehavior == InsertExistingPartitionsBehavior.ER
             }
 
             List<Type> types = dataColumns.stream()
-                    .map(column -> column.getHiveType().getType(typeManager))
+                    .map(column -> column.getHiveType().getType(typeManager, getTimestampPrecision(session).getPrecision()))

nodes.bodyText: we could have a short-cut hiveType.getType(typeManager, session) overload (a potential followup cleanup)
i pushed a fixup for this code
i pushed a fixup for this code
Use @SuppressWarnings rather than a comment

Use format for readability
Also, remove : since saying is 123 reads more naturally than is: 123

I don't think this is a good abstraction. LocalDateTime seems fairly expensive in terms of object allocation and encoding (there's a reason we don't use it everywhere and continue to use Joda-Time). We're also doing the type switching for every value, rather than once for the block or writer instance.
Instead, for the binary encoding, we could inline this into the timestamp writing code (pulling the type switch outside of the block encoding loop). For text encoding, performance is less important, since it's already expensive.
It's possible that this doesn't actually have a performance impact, or that we don't care about RCFile anymore, but since we seem to be introducing a regression to the existing code for millis precision, I'd like to make sure this is an explicit decision (possibly based on data) rather than accidental. @dain probably has more thoughts here.
Can you introduce a method for this? Or default constructor?

commit.message: Construct session correctly when finishing stats collection
Handle variable precision timestamps in MaterializedResult
Variable precision timestamp support for Hive write operations
